Then what? So the trial judge has made a finding of fact on a fact that's not necessary for conviction. Might conceivably have some relevance to the determination. So what is the due process standard for determining whether that requires a new trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Levenstam, I -- I guess I don't understand why you're -- I would have thought that the answer to Justice Alito's question was that Alderson Reporting Company you're not saying that what happened here -- what went wrong here, you're not saying, is that there was a superfluous finding of fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You're saying that there is a superfluous finding of fact that actually went into the judge's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- final determination.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It was not just any old superfluous finding of fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It was not superfluous. It was a made-up finding of fact that created the judge's final conclusion that the man was guilty. That played some role in that final conclusion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- in Taylor --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It depends -- when you're reading this -- in reading what the judge said, it depends on -- the reasonableness of what the judge said may depend on whether you think that the judge inferred that Larry Owens killed the victim because he knew he was a drug dealer, or whether the judge was -- in attempting to fill in the blanks of this case, inferred that he knew he was a drug dealer from the fact that there was proof that he killed him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So if you know that the victim is a drug dealer and the defendant talked to the victim, and then the defendant proceeded to beat his brains out with a baseball bat, you could probably infer from that the reason why he did it was that he knew he was a drug dealer, could you not?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But I -- I'm sorry. You said the problem is with the evidence that linked Alderson Reporting Company him to the --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you're not challenging the sufficiency of that evidence.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that --  seems to me like you're challenging the sufficiency of the evidence, and I --  again, as I --  as the case comes before us, we assume there is sufficient evidence to convict under every element of the crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't make any sense. speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, you're saying we're not challenging the sufficiency of the evidence. We are challenging the Illinois court's determination that it was harmless error that there was not sufficient evidence.

speakers.text: I thought you -- you're Alderson Reporting Company conceding that there was sufficient evidence.
